column1: Royal Tunbridge Wells
column2: previously just Tunbridge Wells
column3: is a town in western Kent
column4: England
column5: 30 miles (48 km) south-east of central London
column6: close to the border with East Sussex upon the northern edge of the High Weald
column7: whose sandstone geology is exemplified by the rock formations at the Wellington Rocks and High Rocks.

column1: The town came into being as a spa in the Restoration and enjoyed its heyday as a fashionable resort in the mid-1700s under Beau Nash when the Pantiles
column2: and its chalybeate spring
column3: attracted significant numbers of visitors who wished to take the waters. Though its popularity as a spa town waned with the advent of sea bathing
column4: the town remains highly popular and derives some 30 per cent of its income from the tourist industry.The town has a population of around 56
column6: and is the administrative centre of Tunbridge Wells Borough and the parliamentary constituency of Tunbridge Wells.

column1: == History ==
Evidence suggests that Iron Age people farmed the fields and mined the iron-rich rocks in the Tunbridge Wells area
column2: and excavations in 1940 and 1957–61 by James Money at High Rocks uncovered the remains of a defensive hill-fort. It is thought that the site was occupied into the era of Roman Britain
column3: and the area continued to be part of the Wealden iron industry until its demise in the late eighteenth century. An iron forge remains in the grounds of Bayham Abbey
column4: in use until 1575 and documented until 1714.

column1: The area which is now Tunbridge Wells was part of the parish of Speldhurst for hundreds of years.The origin of the town today came in the seventeenth century. In 1606 Dudley
column2: Lord North
column3: a courtier to James I who was staying at a hunting lodge in Eridge in the hope that the country air might improve his ailing constitution
column4: discovered a chalybeate spring. He drank from the spring and
column5: when his health improved
column6: he became convinced that it had healing properties. He persuaded his rich friends in London to try it
column7: and by the time Queen Henrietta Maria
column9: visited in 1630 it had established itself as a spa retreat. By 1636 it had become so popular that two houses were built next to the spring to cater for the visitors
column10: one for the ladies and one for the gentlemen
column13: enclosed it with a triangular stone wall
column14: and built a hall "to shelter the dippers in wet weather."Until 1676 little permanent building took place—visitors were obliged either to camp on the downs or to find lodgings at Southborough
column15: —but at this time houses and shops were erected on the walks
column16: and every "convenient situation near the springs" was built upon. Also in 1676 a subscription for a "chapel of ease" was opened
column17: and in 1684 the Church of King Charles the Martyr was duly built and the town began to develop around it. In 1787 Edward Hasted described the new town as consisting of four small districts
column18: "named after the hills on which they stand
column20: Mount Pleasant and Mount Sion; the other is called the Wells..."

column1: The 1680s saw a building boom in the town: carefully planned shops were built beside the 175 yards (160 m) long Pantiles promenade (then known as the Walks)
column2: and the Mount Sion road
column3: on which lodging house keepers were to build
column4: was laid out in small plots. Tradesmen in the town dealt in the luxury goods demanded by their patrons
column5: which would certainly have included Tunbridge ware
column6: a kind of decoratively inlaid woodwork.

column1: They have made the wells very commodious by the many good building all about it and two or three miles around which are lodgings for the company that drink the waters. All the people buy their own provisions at the market, which is just by the wells and is furnished with great plenty of all sorts of fish and fowl. The walk which is between high trees on the market side which are shops full of all sorts of toys, silver, china, milliners and all sorts of curious wooden ware besides which there are two large coffee houses for tea, chocolate etc. and two rooms for the lottery and hazard board (i.e. for gambling).
—Celia Fiennes
Following Richard Russell's 1750 treatise advocating sea water as a treatment for diseases of the glands
column2: fashions in leisure changed and sea bathing became more popular than visiting the spas
column3: which resulted in fewer visitors coming to the town. Nevertheless
column4: the advent of turnpike roads gave Tunbridge Wells better communications—on weekdays a public coach made nine return journeys between Tunbridge Wells and London
column5: and postal services operated every morning except Monday and every evening except Saturday. During the eighteenth century the growth of the town continued
column6: as did its patronage by the wealthy leisured classes—it received celebrity cachet from visits by figures such as Cibber
column9: Richardson and the successful bookseller Andrew Millar and his wife—and in 1735 Richard (Beau) Nash appointed himself as master of ceremonies for all the entertainments that Tunbridge Wells had to offer. He remained in this position until his death in 1762
column10: and under his patronage the town reached the height of its popularity as a fashionable resort.

column1: By the early nineteenth century Tunbridge Wells experienced growth as a place for the well-to-do to visit and make their homes. It became a fashionable resort town again following visits by the Duchess of Kent
column2: Queen Victoria and Prince Albert
column3: and benefited from a new estate on Mount Pleasant and the building of the Trinity church in 1827
column4: and improvements made to the town and the provision of facilities such as gas lighting and a police service meant that by 1837 the town population had swelled to 9
column5: 100. In 1842 an omnibus service was set up that ran from Tonbridge to Tunbridge Wells
column6: enabling visitors to arrive from London within two hours
column7: and in 1845 the town was linked to the railway network via a branch from South Eastern Railway's London-Hastings Hastings Line at Tonbridge. During this time Decimus Burton developed John Ward's Calverley Park estate.In 1889 the town was awarded the status of a Borough
column8: and it entered the 20th century in a prosperous state. 1902 saw the opening of an Opera House
column9: and in 1909 the town received its "Royal" prefix. Due to its position in South East England
column10: during the First World War Tunbridge Wells was made a headquarters for the army
column11: and its hospitals were used to treat soldiers who had been sent home with a "blighty wound"; the town also received 150 Belgian refugees. The Second World War affected Tunbridge Wells in a different way—it became so swollen with refugees from London that accommodation was severely strained. Over 3
column13: but only 15 people lost their lives.Following the war
column14: large-scale housing estates were built at Sherwood and Ramslye to accommodate population growth.

column1: === Toponymy ===
Edward Hasted made the assertion that although the wells were originally named the "Queen's-Wells"
column2: they soon took on the name of Tunbridge Wells due to their proximity to the town of Tonbridge (then known as "Tunbridge"):

column1: In compliment to [queen Henrietta Maria's] doctor
column2: Lewis Rowzee
column3: in his treatise on them
column4: calls these springs the Queen's-wells; but this name lasted but a small time
column5: and they were soon afterwards universally known by that of Tunbridge-wells
column6: which names they acquired from the company usually residing at Tunbridge town
column7: when they came into these parts for the benefit of drinking the waters

column1: —Edward Hasted
The prefix "Royal" dates to 1909
column2: when King Edward VII granted the town its official "Royal" title to celebrate its popularity over the years among members of the royal family. Royal Tunbridge Wells is one of only three towns in England to have been granted this (the others being Royal Leamington Spa and Royal Wootton Bassett).

column1: Although "Wells" has a plural form
column2: it refers to the principal source
column3: the chalybeate spring in the Pantiles (where the waters were taken).

column1: == Governance ==
Royal Tunbridge Wells is the administrative centre for both Tunbridge Wells Borough and the parliamentary constituency of Tunbridge Wells. The Borough is governed by 48 Councillors
column2: representing 20 wards (eight wards fall within the town of Tunbridge Wells itself). Elections are held for 16 Council seats each year on a rotational basis
column3: with elections to Kent County Council taking place in the fourth year of the cycle. Each councillor serves a four-year term.Tunbridge Wells local elections show a pattern since 1973 of Conservative party dominance
column4: apart from a two-year period from 1994 to 1996 of no overall control and a two-year period from 1996 to 1998 when the Liberal Democrats held a majority. By 2008
column5: the Conservatives had a large majority with 44 seats compared with the Liberal Democrats' four. The extent of the Conservatives' dominance is further illustrated by the fact that in some wards (e.g. Park) Labour did not even field a candidate in the 2008 council elections.

column2: the local political situation had changed. In the 2019 local elections
column3: the Conservative majority was cut to 8
column4: and the Council leader David Jukes lost his seat following months of controversy over the Council's plan to borrow £90 million in order to build new council offices
column5: a new 1200-seat theatre
column6: and underground car parking in Calverley Grounds.The Member of Parliament for Tunbridge Wells is the Conservative Greg Clark
column7: whose majority at the 2017 election was 16
column9: Clark was one of 21 Conservative MP's to have the Whip (politics) removed
column10: after failing to back the Government
column11: in keeping the option of a No-deal Brexit on the negotiating table. The constituency has been Conservative since its inception in 1974 for the 1974 General Election; the two previous MPs were Sir Patrick Mayhew (1974–1997) and the former Asda chairman Archie Norman (1997–2005).

column1: == Demography ==
In 2006 the town of Royal Tunbridge Wells was estimated to have a population of approximately 56
column2: 500. The wider borough of Royal Tunbridge Wells is home to considerably more people—some 104
column4: up from around 99
column5: 500 in 1991.The population of Royal Tunbridge Wells is predominantly White and British in its ethnic origin and Christian in its religious affiliation: 97.5% of residents of the district described themselves as white in the 2001 census
column6: and 75.0% identified themselves as being Christian.The statistics for crime in Royal Tunbridge Wells show that in 2005/6 there were fewer crimes occurring in the area than the national average.

column1: == Geography ==
Tunbridge Wells is on the Kentish border with East Sussex
column2: about 31 miles (50 km) south of London; the original centre of the settlement lies directly on the Kent/East Sussex border
column3: as recalled by the county boundary flagstone that still lies outside the church of King Charles the Martyr.

column1: The town is at the northern edge of the High Weald
column2: a ridge of hard sandstone that runs across southern England from Hampshire along the borders of Surrey
column3: West Sussex
column4: East Sussex and Kent—the town's geology is illustrated by the exposed sandstone outcrops at the Wellington Rocks and High Rocks (a Site of Special Scientific Interest due to its exposed gulls)
column5: and the quarries at nearby Langton Green from which sandstone was taken to build houses in Tunbridge Wells. The town is sited at the head of a valley that runs south-east to Groombridge; like the River Teise
column6: which originates in Tunbridge Wells
column7: the stream in the valley is one of the many tributaries of the River Medway
column8: which runs through a much larger valley north of the High Weald.

column1: Nearby villages have been subsumed into the built-up area of the town
column2: so that now it incorporates High Brooms to the north
column3: Hawkenbury to the south
column4: and Rusthall (whose name resonates with the iron content of the rocks) to the west.

column1: === Twinning ===
Royal Tunbridge Wells is twinned with:
Wiesbaden
column2: GermanyIn 1960
column3: through an advertisement in the national press
column4: contact was made between former paratroopers in Wiesbaden and four English ex-servicemen in Royal Tunbridge Wells. Through this contact the friendship that now exists between the two towns sprang up
column5: leading to the signing in 1989 of the official Twinning Charter. Also through this the Tunbridge Wells Twinning and Friendship Association (TWTFA) was formed.

column1: === Climate ===
Tunbridge Wells
column2: like the rest of Britain
column3: has a temperate maritime climate
column4: lacking in weather extremes. The nearest official weather station is Goudhurst
column5: about 8.5 mi (14 km) to the east of the town centre.

column1: The absolute maximum temperature in Goudhurst stands at 34.7 °C (94.5 °F)
column2: recorded in August 1990
column3: compared to the average annual warmest day maximum of 28.7 °C (83.7 °F). In total
column4: 11.8 days should attain a temperature of 25.1 °C (77.2 °F) or above.

column1: The absolute minimum temperature recorded in Goudhurst was −19.2 °C (−2.6 °F) during January 1940
column2: compared to the average annual coldest night minimum of −8.3 °C (17.1 °F). In total 52.8 nights should report an air frost.

column1: Annual rainfall averages in Goudhurst 823.3 mm (32.41 in)
column2: with over 1 mm (0 in) falling on 120.7 days.

column1: == Economy ==
The economy of the town no longer depends on the chalybeate spring. Hardly anyone comes to the town purely to take the waters.
As of 2002 there were around 50
column2: 000 people employed in the borough of Tunbridge Wells. The largest sector of the local economy consists of hotels
column3: restaurants
column4: and retail (the centrally located Royal Victoria Place shopping centre
column5: opened in 1992
column6: covers 29
column9: which accounts for around 30% of all jobs; the finance and business sector makes up just under a quarter of jobs
column11: education and health sector. Royal Tunbridge Wells is arguably the most important retail centre between London and Hastings.

column1: The largest single employer in the town used to be the Maidstone and Tunbridge Wells NHS Trust
column2: at the Kent and Sussex and Tunbridge Wells Hospitals
column3: employing around 2500 people; the largest single commercial employer was AXA PPP healthcare
column4: employing around 1
column5: 700 in four offices (PPP House
column6: Union House
column7: Phillips House and International House). Tunbridge Wells had a relatively low unemployment rate of around 1.0% in August 2008
column8: compared to a UK national rate of around 5.4%.

column1: == Transport ==
Tunbridge Wells is at the hub of a series of roads
column2: the primary ones being the A26
column3: which runs from Maidstone to Newhaven; the A264
column4: which runs from Five Oaks to Pembury (via Crawley and East Grinstead); and the A267
column5: which runs south from Tunbridge Wells to Hailsham. The A21 passes to the east of the town
column6: following the route of its turnpike ancestor

column1: Bus services are operated chiefly by Arriva Kent & Sussex
column2: providing local town and rural services to Tonbridge
column3: Paddock Wood and Sevenoaks
column4: as well as express services to locations such as Bromley and Maidstone. Eastbourne and Brighton on the south coast are accessible on services run by Stagecoach in Eastbourne and Brighton & Hove respectively
column5: and Metrobus operates hourly services to Crawley.

column1: Tunbridge Wells town historically had three railway stations: two of these are still in use by National Rail services. Tunbridge Wells station is
column2: as its former name of Tunbridge Wells Central suggests
column3: centrally located within the town at the end of the High Street
column4: whilst High Brooms station is situated in High Brooms
column5: to the north of the town. Both stations are located on the double-tracked electrified Hastings Line; services are operated by the Southeastern train operating company.

column1: Tunbridge Wells West station was opened by the London
column2: Brighton and South Coast Railway in 1866 as the terminus of its competing line to Tunbridge Wells
column3: but closed in 1985 along with that line. The station building—a Grade II listed building—is now a restaurant
column4: and a Sainsbury's supermarket occupies the former goods yard. In 1996
column5: however
column6: part of the line was reopened by the Tunbridge Wells and Eridge Railway Preservation Society
column7: which now—as the Spa Valley Railway—operates a steam heritage railway that runs from Tunbridge Wells West to Eridge via High Rocks and Groombridge. The western end of the service was extended from Groombridge to Eridge
column8: on the London-Uckfield line of Southern Railway
column10: serving a platform at Eridge which had been disused for many years. The tunnelled link line between the West and erstwhile Central stations

column1: In 2009 Network Rail installed a 12-car turnback siding just south of Tunbridge Wells station between the Grove Hill and Strawberry Hill tunnels to facilitate a more frequent service and to allow restricted types of London trains starting or terminating at Tunbridge Wells to be operated in 12-car formations. Previously such services were 11-car at most.Average daily passenger flows on trains between Tunbridge Wells and London have increased from about 10
column2: 000 in 1999 to over 12
column4: a compound growth rate of about 2.5% per year. Average daily passenger flows between Tunbridge Wells and Sevenoaks
column5: and between Tunbridge Wells and Tonbridge
column6: have grown considerably faster
column7: though are still much smaller than the flows between Tunbridge Wells and London.

column1: == Education ==
Kent County Council is one of fifteen local authorities in the UK that still provides selective education through the eleven plus exam.
Royal Tunbridge Wells does not have a university of its own
column2: but the Salomons Campus of Canterbury Christ Church University is located just outside the town (near Southborough) and provides postgraduate programmes.

column1: == Sports ==
=== Football ===
Tunbridge Wells' football team
column2: Tunbridge Wells F.C.
column3: plays in the Southern Counties East Football League at the Culverden Stadium
column4: and has a history that stretches back to 1886. Tunbridge Wells F.C. were finalists in the 2013 FA Vase and competed at Wembley Stadium on 4 May
column5: coming second to Spennymoor Town F.C..

column1: === Motorsport ===
Tunbridge Wells Motor Club is one of the oldest motor clubs in the UK
column2: being founded in 1911. It is still active in the Tunbridge Wells area promoting grass roots motorsport organising an autotest series and several sprint races throughout the year at circuits such as Lydden Hill and Goodwood.

column1: === Rugby union ===
Tunbridge Wells RFC plays its home games at St Mark's
column2: and plays London & South East Premier Rugby at RFU level 5.

column1: === Rugby League ===
Weald Warriors RLFC are a Rugby League team based in the town
column2: also at St Mark's. The Warriors were founded in 2012 and currently compete in the 4th tier of English rugby league in the London & South East Men's League.

column1: === Cricket ===
The Nevill Ground hosts county and international cricket
column2: and Kent County Cricket Club uses it regularly as one of its outgrounds. Tunbridge Wells came into the cricketing spotlight during the 1983 Cricket World Cup when Kapil Dev and Syed Kirmani had an unbroken partnership of 126 for India against Zimbabwe at the Nevill Ground on 6 July 1983; this is the second highest partnership for the 9th wicket in a one-day international. Also based at the Nevill Ground is Tunbridge Wells Hockey Club
column3: which competes in the Kent/Sussex Regional (men) and East Premier (women) divisions.

column1: Linden Park Cricket Club
column2: which plays in local leagues
column3: hosts its home matches at the Higher Cricket Ground on Tunbridge Wells Common.

column1: === Swimming ===
The RTW Monson Swimming Club competes in swimming
column2: diving and water polo and is based at the Tunbridge Wells Sports Centre. Former Monson member Joanne Rout
column3: née Round
column4: took part in the Swimming events at the 1988 Summer Paralympics in Seoul
column5: aged just 12
column6: winning two relay Gold Medals (also setting two new world records) and three individual Silver Medals; and as of 2012 remains the youngest ever British Paralympian. A plaque can be found located in the club's trophy display. Tunbridge Wells Borough Council honoured Joanne with the award of their Civic Medallion after her return from Seoul in recognition of her efforts and achievements at such a young age.

column1: === Running ===
The Tunbridge Wells Half Marathon is an open road race that takes place every February
column2: organised by the Tunbridge Wells Harriers running club. There is also a weekly 5K Park Run that takes place in Dunorlan Park.

column1: === Squash ===
Tunbridge Wells Squash Club on London Road is a traditional Squash (sport) club with three courts. There are internal leagues for squash and racquetball
column2: and both men's and ladies' teams in the Kent Priory squash league. Squash facilities are also available at the Tunbridge Wells Sports centre on St John's Rd. which also has a club competing in the Kent priory league.

column1: === Curling ===
Fenton's Rink is situated in Dundale Farm near Tunbridge Wells. It is the only dedicated curling ice rink in England.
== Public services ==
Health services are provided by the West Kent Primary Care Trust. Maidstone and Tunbridge Wells NHS Trust runs the new Tunbridge Wells Hospital at Pembury (usually referred to as Pembury Hospital)
column2: nearly three miles (4.8 km) from the town
column3: which opened in 2011.

column1: Royal Tunbridge Wells is policed by Kent Police
column2: and in May 2000 the main police station for the area moved from Royal Tunbridge Wells to a new building in Tonbridge and operations at the Royal Tunbridge Wells station
column3: in Crescent Road
column4: were scaled back so that it now operates as an administrative centre. Fire services are carried out by Kent Fire and Rescue Service
column5: which operates one station in Grove Hill Road that is manned 24 hours a day by both full-time and retained firefighters.

column1: The electricity Distribution Network Operator is UK Power Networks
column2: and water services are managed by Southern Water; the main reservoir in the area is Bewl Water.

column1: The Kent and Sussex Crematorium and Cemetery opened in 1873
column2: known initially as the Frant Forest Cemetery due to its location
column3: laid out over 23 acres (9.3 ha) by the then town surveyor.

column1: Royal Tunbridge Wells also has a library
column2: museum and art gallery in Civic Way.

column1: == Cultural references ==
Tunbridge Wells is mentioned in Arthur Conan Doyle's The Valley of Fear
column2: H. G. Wells' Christina Alberta's Father
column3: Thomas Pynchon's Gravity's Rainbow
column4: Philip Reeve's Mortal Engines
column5: E. M. Forster's A Room with a View
column6: Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest
column7: Arnold Bennett's The Old Wives' Tale
column8: and Zadie Smith's White Teeth. The Inspector Bone mysteries by Susannah Stacey are also set in and around Tunbridge Wells. In Fanny Burney's 1796 novel Camilla
column9: several characters make an excursion to Tunbridge Wells
column10: and there are many references to The Pantiles and other local sites.

column1: In Bleak House by Charles Dickens the children find a mug in the cupboard entitled "A Present From Tunbridge Wells."
David Lean's epic film Lawrence of Arabia closes with Mr. Dryden answering King Feisal: "Me
column2: your Highness? On the whole
column3: I wish I'd stayed in Tunbridge Wells"
column4: and in the James Bond film On Her Majesty's Secret Service Tracy Di Vicenzo says to Bond that she "looks forward to living as Mr and Mrs James Bond of Acacia Avenue
column5: Tunbridge Wells".

column1: Tunbridge Wells is referenced in another of David Lean's films
column2: A Passage to India
column3: in which Mrs. Moore (Peggy Ashcroft) exclaims about the odious wife of the District Collector that "My only consolation is that Mrs. Turton will soon be retired to a villa in Tunbridge Wells." Less well known is H. G. Wells's sending up in his 1925 book Christina Alberta's Father: "Tunbridge Wells is Tunbridge Wells
column4: and there is nothing really like it upon our planet".In Spitting Image
column5: when Britain enters a revolution
column6: Royal Tunbridge Wells declares independence under the slogan of 'liberty
column8: gardening'.In the TV sketch comedy series Rutland Weekend Television
column9: there is a musical sketch that tells the tale of three US Navy sailors who plan to spend an exciting—"More exciting than a book of Norman Mailer's"—and glamour-filled 24 hours in Royal Tunbridge Wells.In the UK
column10: the town has a reputation for being a bastion of the middle class and a typical example of "Middle England". This is reflected in the locution "Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells"
column11: first used by a fictional writer of letters to national newspapers in the 1950s
column12: to express outrage and defend conservative values.

column1: == Parks and landmarks ==
The Pantiles and its chalybeate spring have been the landmarks most readily associated with Royal Tunbridge Wells ever since the founding of the town
column2: though the 5-metre-high (16 ft) steel Millennium Clock at the Fiveways area in the centre of town
column3: designed by local sculptor Jon Mills for the Millennium celebrations
column4: stakes a claim to be a modern landmark.Tunbridge Wells contains green spaces that range from woodland to maintained grounds and parks. The most substantial areas of woodland are the Tunbridge Wells and Rusthall Commons
column5: which comprise 250 acres (0.39 sq mi; 1.0 km2) of wood and heathland and are close to the centre of the town. Open areas of the common are popular picnic spots
column6: and there is a maintained cricket ground situated next to Wellington Rocks.

column1: Located in the town centre opposite the railway station
column2: Calverley Grounds is a historic park with ornamental gardens and a bandstand (now demolished). The park was part of Mount Pleasant House
column3: which was converted into a hotel in 1837
column4: until 1920 when the Borough Council purchased it for the town. The bandstand dated from 1924 and was damaged by an incendiary bomb in 1940 and parts of the metalwork were sold for scrap metal. The subsequently repaired bandstand and the adjacent pavilion were intended to form part of a new centre to the park but were never completed. The bandstand was demolished in 2010 although the pavilion still exists as a café. Just inside the entrance to the park coming from the station is a memorial to Air Chief Marshal Lord Dowding
column5: hero of the Battle of Britain
column6: who lived and died in Tunbridge Wells.Dunorlan Park
column7: at 78 acres (0.122 sq mi; 0.32 km2) the largest maintained green space in the town
column8: was once a private garden that was part of the millionaire Henry Reed's now demolished mansion
column9: and only passed into public possession in 1941. The gardens were designed by the Victorian gardener James Green
column10: but over the years they became overgrown
column11: making it hard to distinguish the full scope of Marnock's design. In 1996 Tunbridge Wells Borough Council applied to the Heritage Lottery Fund for a grant to restore the park in line with the original designs
column12: and in 2003/4 Dunorlan underwent a £2.8 million restoration. The River Teise rises in the park
column13: and two dams on it have created a pond and a boating lake. Dunorlan is listed as Grade II on English Heritage's National Register of Historic Parks and Gardens.Great Culverden Park is a small
column14: 9½ acre woodland in the Mount Ephraim area behind the site of the old Kent and Sussex Hospital and is the remnant grounds of the previous Great Culverden House designed by Decimus Burton that used to stand on Mount Ephraim.

column1: The oldest public park in Royal Tunbridge Wells is Grosvenor Recreation Ground designed by landscape architect Robert Marnock
column2: located close to the town centre on Quarry Road. It was opened in 1889 by Mayor John Stone-Wigg
column3: on the land that was formerly Caverley Waterworks.  The lake area with dripping wells remains
column4: but the other lakes
column5: bandstand and open air pool have all gone. There is a bowls club
column6: café
column8: including cycle track. It is adjoined by the Hilbert recreation ground
column9: parts of which have been designated as a local nature reserve by the Kent High Weald Partnership; these include Roundabout Woods and the adjoining grass areas. The Hilbert Recreation Ground was donated to the town by Cllr Edward Strange in 1931
column10: on the site of the form John Beane's Charity Farm. There are two football pitches
column11: built as part of the King George V playing fields scheme
column12: and a skatepark.The Salomons Museum preserves the home of David Salomons
column13: the first Jew to serve as Lord Mayor of London and the first non-Christian to sit in Parliament. It preserves the bench from which Salomons rose to speak as the first Jewish MP ever to speak in Parliament.

column1: == The arts ==
The town's largest theatre is the Assembly Hall in Crescent Road
column2: which has a capacity of 1020. Nearby
column3: in Church Road
column4: is the Trinity Arts Centre which is a converted church.

column1: The Forum is a 250-capacity live music venue in the town
column2: run by Jason Dormon
column3: where many bands have played their early concerts on their way to success.Unfest is an annual free music festival which takes place in May.Royal Tunbridge Wells held its first TEDxRoyalTunbridgeWells on 6 June 2015.

column1: == Local media ==
Royal Tunbridge Wells has one local commercial radio station
column2: KMFM West Kent. The BBC has its regional centre in the town at the Great Hall on Mount Pleasant Road. It is the base of BBC Radio Kent and for BBC South East regional programmes
column3: the complex contains studios and offices.
